description: Hard-hitting live jazz fusion, 8-bit, glitch and EDM music from bassist/YouTuber Adam Neely and drummer Shawn Crowder. Originally formed in Brooklyn, NY, Sungazer had brought their unique blend of organic and digital music to audiences in the U.S. and Europe. Sungazer explores the human element of improvisation within the context of the modern electronic music paradigm.

name: CS:GO Casting
description: Come watch the finale of CS:GO in the LAN Theatre!

name: Super Ultra Fighting Instinct EX Turbo Remix Alpha Larp
description: Friday 4-7 The Collision, Inevitable. The Impact, Unavoidable. The Emotions, Palpable. SUFIETRA is a Semi-Free Form Larp focused on the behind the scene goings on at an international fighting tournament, like those popularized in early 1990’s video game. Take on the role of a World Warrior, a master of the martial arts with more emotional baggage than one person should be able to bear and compete in the first-ever Emperor of the Steel Fist Tournament. The prize? Your wildest dreams come true, all you have to do is come face to face with everyone who’s ever broken your heart, ruined your life, or meant a damn to you..

name: Paper, Please: Lessons From Three Decades of Video Game Fanzines
description:
Before dial-up internet forever changed one-to-many communication, video game fans, like science fiction fans before them, shared their views on games by exchanging copies of handmade publications––fanzines. Video game fanzines are sometimes crude, sometimes incisive, but always idiosyncratic, the products of unmistakably individual minds. In this talk, librarian Michael Hughes will discuss the history of game fandom’s print culture, including its little-remembered origins in "Joystick Jolter", a newsletter from New Jersey. He'll also discuss why fanzines matter, not just for their informational content but, in the words of Sherry Turkle, as “companions to our emotional lives or as provocations to thought”.

Panelist:
Michael Hughes is an instruction librarian and associate professor at Trinity University. His research interests include game cultures, player-generated content, and media fandom generally. Michael's writing can be found in scholarly journals, including First Monday and portal: Libraries and the Academy, and at VGMO: Video Game Music Online. This is either his first time at MAGFest or he's having a wonderful dream at home in San Antonio. If the latter, don't wake him.

name: Ethics and Videogames: An Overview of Ethical Considerations and Implications of Videogames
description: This presentation puts topics related to violence in videogames, games as an educational tool, and the diversity of game creators into a discussion through an ethical framework. Videogames are ethical objects and game players are ethical agents, therefore both are imbued with ethical and even moral responsibilities that are challenged during gameplay. Ethics and videogames share in a dialectical conversation and this presentation explores exactly what that conversation entails.

name: Whose Roll is it Anyway?
description: Join the "greatest" RPG in the Multiverse*! Watch in horror and fascination as our Dungeon Master leads a band of Heroes through an adventure of YOUR CREATION! That's right, grognards: YOU birth the monsters. YOU forge the magic items. YOU will set the romantic tension aflame. A few of you will even get the chance to join us on stage!  Heroes will rise. Dice will roll. Wizards of the Coast will probably sue.

name: James Landino Tells All Q&A: The Road to Fulltime
description: Professional game composer, DJ, project manager, game developer, and more: James Landino's path to a career in music and is an expansive journey. James describes his experiences and answers questions that outline how a musician transitions from a hobby to a career in the industry.

name: Mega Man 11
description:
For the entire duration that the Mega Man-athon has existed, there hasn't been a new Mega Man game until now. Watch as TheSkipper1995 plays through and points out everything special about the game!

3:50 - 5:00 PM

name: XR (VR/AR): More than Gaming
description:
Our goal is to discuss some of the realities of XR (VR/AR). We will be exploring what current fields are using XR to to disrupt industries outside of gaming:
Engineering, Advertising, Education,  Architecture, Clinical Therapy Use.

name: Top Ten Episodes of Transformers
description: From the first episodes of Gen-1 through the most recent episode of Cyberverse and everything in-between, join this countdown of the ten absolute best episodes of the long-running Transformers franchise.

name: Filters, Bell Curves, and Q OH MY!: A Primer on Equalization and other Frequency Based Processing.
description: From shaping tone to fixing poor recording technique, frequency based signal processing like equalization is used by the mixing and mastering engineer to repair or enhance elements in a mix.  In this lecture Dr. Cresci will discuss the harmonic content of sound, origins of EQ, standard plugin concepts,  and various usage techniques.

name: Fighting Dragons in Your Mind: A Beginner's Guide to D&D
description: Do you want to play Dungeons & Dragons but don't know where to start? What's with these weird dice? How can you play a game with no board? What are all these books? Are we the dungeons or the dragons? Join the Mythmakers team as we go over the answers to these questions and everything else you need to get started playing the widely popular tabletop roleplaying game!

Bring your instrument (or try our in-house gear), grab a microphone, and get ready to jam with our highly-talented staff and guests! Or just swing by and enjoy the live music! Not sure where to start, or want to brush up on your chops? We have workshops scheduled throughout the weekend for all skill levels.

Note: time ranges for Open and Guided Jams may vary slightly due to scheduled events in the Jam Clinic and Jam Shop.

~~~

The Jam Clinic is a musician-to-musician education venue at the Music and Gaming Festival (MAGFest), dedicated to co-mentoring participants on how to play and improvise within genres such as jazz fusion, funk, and rock, as well as popular video game music.

We strive to teach participants and empower them with the language of musical communication, while embracing a leadership-centered, technology-powered, challenging, and fun atmosphere for our visitors.

name: Overwatch 6v6 Tournament
description: Grab your team and pick your hero in this objective-based FPS.  Note: this tournament is a two-day event, with the final few matching being shoutcasted on Saturday at 11am in the LAN Theatre.  Please plan accordingly.

description: My Gamedev Bootcamp panel is an introduction to game development in which many facets of game development - code, audio, art, and more - are discussed in a way that should empower anyone at any skill level to start creating games.

description: Hosted by Chuggaaconroy, Nintendo Capri Sun and Proton Jon, Thrown Controllers is a video game trivia gameshow where contestants will have their knowledge of video games and their gaming skills put to the test.  You'll have to answer trivia questions, name that tune, play games against the audience and more!  The more questions and challenges you can clear, the better prize you get at the end, and there's a grand prize for the player with the highest score.  You'll need a lot of skill and a little luck to go the distance.  Do you have what it takes to be the best, or will the Brutal Question shut you down?

description:
MAGFest SMASH! Class 1-A is strugglings to come up with an idea for their school’s next festival.  Will they fail, or go PLUS ULTRA!? Feel free to laugh and cheer during this comedic dance show as Class 1-A tries to be the number one hero class! All Heroes and Villians are all welcomed to this all ages show! You should really baku-GO to this performance!

Fusing the theatrics of acting with a mix of cosplay, pop-culture, and off-beat humor Antipode brings the audience not just dance, but full geek entertainment.

name: Homebrew, Hacking, and History
description:
Ever wondered how new games get made for old game consoles like the NES? In this panel, 8-bit game developer and historian Rachel Simone Weil will discuss the history and artistry of hacking and writing games for obsolete game consoles from the 1970s to the 2000s.

Panelist:
Rachel Simone Weil is an artist and video game historian whose work centers on preserving and reimagining femme aesthetics in 8- and 16-bit console gaming. She brings girly and glitchy visuals to obsolete hardware and game consoles, creating interactive electronic art that has been shown internationally in venues ranging from chipmusic festivals to fine art galleries. In 2012, Weil founded FEMICOM Museum, a physical and online collection of twentieth-century games and electronic toys for girls.

name: Ultima: An Analysis of Final Fantasy Music
description: Welcome to Music Theory class, but not the boring kind. Come listen to music theorists discuss music from Final Fantasy! Enter the World of Final Fantasy, and learn how the music drives emotion and storytelling; how it subjugates the human psyche, and how it establishes the tone of an unfolding narrative. Whether it’s the melancholic feel of “To Zanarkand” to the cheery and repetitive texture of the Chocobo theme, we will point to the melodies, harmonies, and music development that guides you through the action. Music underscores every aspect of a video game's development, and we will show how the importance of the music develop settings, builds emotion, and creates a persona and tool to tell a story with no words.

name: How to create audio for your game without a budget
description: Do you have a game or maybe a movie? Now you need sounds and you have no money. This panel endeavors to show you how to create original immersive sound without a budget. What to expect? A short lecture, some video examples, and hands-on participation with the tools of my daily trade. Followed by a Q&A session.

description: In this workshop (for all skill levels and instruments, believe it or not!), Adam will lead a series of specially designed rhythm games for teaching polyrhythms, polymeters, phasing, and just in general doing cool things with interlocking patterns. Drawing on the music of Terry Riley, Steve Reich, John Adams and other minimalist headbangers, these games will get you in the mood to groove hard.

name: Trash-talking during video games: A look at the research
description: How does trash-talking impact video gaming? Research tells us that it’s more complicated than you might think.  In this discussion, we’ll take a look at the current research on trash-talking, and discuss how the effects of trash-talking can change depending on the game you play or who you play with.  Come join us if you’re interested in learning more!

name: DINNER BREAK

name: Gamifying Blackness: A Discussion on African-American Portrayals in Contemporary Videogames
description: The topic will be focused on the relationship between virtual environments and people, specifically the relationship between videogames and social actors (game player, game producers, publishers, etc.) This conversation will be centered around identifying and contextualizing the representations of black people in videogames and in real spaces. This is an open-ended conversation in which to discuss what it means to be accurately represented in videogames, tracing a brief history of black stereotypes in games, and overall the current state of being black in gaming culture. Representations can embody values and beliefs, and representation can be a site for conflict and contention.

name: insaneintherain
description: Carlos Eiene (insaneintherainmusic) is an American / Filipino tenor saxophonist, pianist, and online content creator. Best known for his 2016 release “Live at Grillby’s”, Carlos produces jazz arrangements of video game music, and posts them on his YouTube channel “insaneintherainmusic”. Carlos’ 2017 album “Alola that Jazz” debuted at #6 on the iTunes Jazz Charts. Additionally, Carlos is currently a student at the Berklee College of Music, pursuing a degree in Contemporary Writing & Production.

name: Latin Dancing for Nerds
description: It's time to learn a new skill! We will be diving into the world of Latin dancing, learning one of the most popular partner dances called Bachata. This is a beginner friendly lesson where we will go through all the basic steps needed for you to get out on the dance floor. The music we'll be dancing to will be a mix of traditional Bachata songs, as well as remixes of popular gaming tracks. Cosplay is highly encouraged. No partner necessary but you're more than welcome to bring your favorite human! Let's dance.

name: Demoscene Effects Basics Workshop
description: Javascript-based workshops explaining simple algorithms and teaching to implement some simple 2D-based effects. Presenter: Jakub “Argasek” Argasinski

name: Mastering the Ultimate Legacy Game: American Government
description:
Governments are like board games, with players & resources, turns & actions, advances & setbacks, all governed by a set of shared rules. The biggest difference between governments and board games was that governments could change the rules as you played -- until legacy-styled board games like Pandemic Legacy and Seafall let their players change the rules too.

To master the “ultimate legacy game” of American government, we’ll explore lessons learned from playing legacy-styled games, uncover historic parallels, and see if there are related strategies for success we can apply to civic education.

name: Square Enix vs. Bethesda: Music in Storytelling through RPGs
description: In present-day video games, music is a huge factor in building up both storylines and worlds. Different cultures have different ways of treating music in regards to their storytelling, especially between Japanese and American cultures. This panel will analyze various well-known roleplaying games in both cultures, such as Final Fantasy, Kingdom Hearts, Skyrim, and Dragon Age, and examine how each culture uses music in a unique way to flesh out its stories.

name: Mundane Life Simulator: A Workshop on Making Anything Fun
description: When we asked Valve about how to get into the gaming industry, one piece of advice they gave was to think about the mundane everyday things and make that into a game. They argue that “anything can be turned into a game.” So let’s follow Valve’s advice and make anything and everything into a game! Bring your ideas and we’ll do a live workshop, determining goals and resources for life’s everyday quests.

name: Make a Video Game Cookie Cutter
description: Cookie cutters let you bake and decorate cookies in your favorite shapes, but it can be difficult to find them in the shape of our favorite video game icons.  Learn how to design, pattern, and build your own metal cookie cutter using basic tools and materials (no 3D printers needed!).  Each student will be provided with a blank strip and tools needed to craft their own cutter to take home with them.  Use a stock pattern that we provide, or stretch your creativity and design your own!

description: Join members of Uplift: Online Communities Against Sexual Violence to discuss consent and how the rules apply online and off.  Participate in a discussion of how consent plays out in gaming communities and learn mechanisms for creating positive spaces within these communities.

name: HoloLens: Designed for Mixed Reality
description: Mixed reality (MR), one of the latest development in VR, is the merging of virtual worlds with the real world. Among others, Microsoft is leading the way with the HoloLens, a mixed reality device that overlays holographic images on top of a users view for training, remote collaboration, and real-time information sharing. Join representative from Microsoft as they introduce HoloLens and talk about designing for it.

name: The History of Japanese Board Gaming
description: Join a Japanese board game aficionado and historian as we look back over Japanese board game history.... way back! Sure, Japan's made tons of video game franchises we know and love today, but did you know Nintendo started as a playing card maker? Ever shouted Richi at a table of four? We'll be covering some of the classics- real classics- all the way to some of Japan's modern board game wonders like Love Letter.

Garcia of the band Smoochyface, audience participants are invited to sing along to their favorite 90's jams with a live band! But there's a catch: the band is also made of volunteers and audience members who have never practiced the songs--which are selected at random with a "Wheel of Tunes". It's hilarious, chaotic, and triumphant fun for all!

description: Come watch the finals of the Dota 2 tournament in the LAN Theatre as the teams duke it out on the glorious theatre stage!

name: Red Dead Redemption: Nightmare Larp
description: January, Valentine New Hanover, 1897. A damnable mix of ice and snow has been falling for a week straight. The town of Valentine is used to a little snowfall but this is unheard of. Everyone in town (and some outsiders) have taken refuge at the Rolling Pony Inn, The hotel, abr and house of Ill repute on account of it being the warmest place in town, but no one expected to be here for this long. Tensions are running high, old feuds being brought up, food’s running low and so is the booze. Something’s gonna give soon an’ it don’t help matter’s none that some of the folk keep looking out the windows and saying they see something looking back at them in through the storm. Ain’t a thing alive that could make it through this storm. Red Dead Redemption: Nightmare is a Parlour Larp for 20+ players. Come play a member of the town and weather the storm together… or not.

name: Pathfinder: History of Game Development
description: Come talk to Paizo organized play manager Tonya Woldridge about the history of the Pathfinder roleplaying game and how it was developed from D&D 3.5. What lessons were learned, what hurdles were crossed, and how did they inform the development of Starfinder and Pathfinder 2.0?

description: Attendees will be able to drive VEX IQ robots on a 4x16 foot field and score goals using a 3 inch rubber ball.  The game is played 2 on 2 and winners will qualify for the finals through a series of qualification rounds.  Tournament winners will be decided through a single elimination bracket.

name: Cosplay Chess
description: Have you ever wanted to see your favorite characters battle it out? Now you can in this live game of chess, Cosplay Chess. Here your favorite characters will assume the role of chess pieces as they are maneuvered around on our giant chessboard by their Chess Masters. You do not need prior chess experience to participate or to enjoy this event. You never know what could happen in this exciting game. So come check out Cosplay Chess and see who will hold the title of victory.

name: Esports and Education: Game on!
description: This panel will explore where Esports fits into education, both from the competitive side of things and from the academic side. We are seeing more and more universities, and even high schools now, have competitive teams with coaches and scholarships.  We are also seeing more academic courses and certificates in esport education available than even before...and it's growing!

name: Making games based on the arts
description:
In this design panel, experienced game designers and artists describe their work with crossovers between games and the arts: informing attendees about this growing sector filled with meaningful and novel games.  

As game design gains ground in museums, education, and other cultural spaces, finding connections between games and the arts is more important than ever.  Topics for the talk include: Selecting works to be the basis of your game, designing game mechanics based on works of art and literature, choosing the right medium and materials for your game, and finding ways to sell or exhibit your art and humanities-inspired games.

name: Wave the Wind Waker: A Conducting Workshop
description: The gestures and methods that conductors have used to bring our favorite orchestral soundtracks remain an arcane mystery to many. This workshop aims to pierce the veil by providing select attendees the rare opportunity to take the podium and direct a chamber orchestra as they perform choice repertoire from top VGM soundtracks. The workshop will begin with a lecture and demonstration by experienced conductors of the GSO Maryland, the Irish Video Game Orchestra, and the Game Music Ensemble at UCLA. However, the bulk of the workshop will be time spent giving individualized instruction to our participants.

name: Game Music for the Future
description: Alexander Brandon has been writing game music for 25 years. That's a good while. Not many composers from the 80s and 90s are still at it. And new generations flock to the classics it seems more than the modern stuff. Why is that? Let's take a stab at it together. I also want to impart as much knowledge as possible to those interested in this field. So this will be half talky talk and half Q&A.

description: It is hard to keep tracking of the changing envoriments in the VR community.  Steve will explore what 2019 means for Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality & Mixed Reality. If you don’t know the difference, he will explain this too, by telling you about all the hardware, software and accessories that are available today.

name: The Bards Among Us: The Importance of Music in Roleplaying Games
description: There is nothing like immersion when playing roleplaying games. Utilizing music as sensory stimulus is a trick that game creators and writers have been using since the dawn of time. Join an in-depth discussion with role playing experts with varying experiences, across a variety of musical backgrounds. Moderated by artist Matthew Munson. Featuring panelists; Sound Engineer Cole Burkhardt, Singer/Writer Jae Lynn, and Dancer/Choreographer/Instructor Lodestar. Sponsored by Reframe.

description: Cut Throat Cosplay is a game show 3 teams of expert builders go head to head with an hour to build costumes out of random scraps. Every 5 minutes, the teams may be sabotaged due to efforts made by the audience. Audience members may have to compete in physical challenges or answer trivia questions in order for their team to remain on top. It's like MacGuyver meets JoAnn Fabrics in the Thunder Dome.

name: Learning Reaper: The Best Digital Audio Workstation No One Knows About
description: The Digital Audio Workstation, DAW, Reaper is one of the most flexible and complete DAWs on the market today. Created by the maker of WinAmp, it is supported by a loyal fan base that is continually adding functionality. It is being adopted by many freelance engineers, studios and game companies as their DAW of choice. In this lecture we will be exploring this DAW. We will walk through all of the Idiosyncrasies and demystify the operation of this DAW by deconstructing a full mix.

name: Wingin' It with Freddie Wong and Anthony Burch
description: For a third time, Internet Superstar Freddie Wong will team up with Beta Soy Boy Anthony Burch to crack jokes and take questions.

name: The Cost is Correct
description: MAGFest, COME ON DOWN! You could be the next contestant on our fabulous, legally distinct version of a popular TV pricing game show. Contestants chosen from our live studio audience will bid on a variety of gaming/nerd-related items for a chance to play our pricing games, spin the big (virtual) wheel, and maybe even price out one of our fabulous Showcases. No, you won't win the prizes you're bidding on, but there will be prizes!

name: Aesthetics in Game Design or: Why Balloon Fight is Better than Joust.
description: In 1984 Nintendo released Balloon Fight, a clone of Midway's hit arcade game Joust. Despite having practically identical gameplay, Balloon Fight continues to live on through rereleases and homage while Joust becomes more of a memory for those who were there at the time. This panel will compare and contrast the two games through the lens of game and graphic design analysis to show how Balloon Fight goes above and beyond being a simple clone by utilizing Nintendo's unique approach to style, design and brand identity.

description: Learn from game audio veteran Alexander Brandon the fundamentals of Audiokinetic's Wwise! Free to use with up to 200 files, you can get started right away. Alex will take you through the basic features and how they're used in real-world game scenarios, with an emphasis on interactive music.

name: Open and Guided Jams
description:
Bring your instrument (or try our in-house gear), grab a microphone, and get ready to jam with our highly-talented staff and guests! Or just swing by and enjoy the live music! Not sure where to start, or want to brush up on your chops? We have workshops scheduled throughout the weekend for all skill levels.

Note: time ranges for Open and Guided Jams may vary slightly due to scheduled events in the Jam Clinic and Jam Shop.

~~~

The Jam Clinic is a musician-to-musician education venue at the Music and Gaming Festival (MAGFest), dedicated to co-mentoring participants on how to play and improvise within genres such as jazz fusion, funk, and rock, as well as popular video game music.

We strive to teach participants and empower them with the language of musical communication, while embracing a leadership-centered, technology-powered, challenging, and fun atmosphere for our visitors.

name: Steven Universe: Gay Space Rocks
description: Steven Universe holds an extra special place in the hearts of LGBTQ+ fans. It's easy to see why - but the connection runs much deeper. From central themes, to characters, to relationships - we'll examine in detail how Steven Universe relates to the queer experience. Join us and get a broader perspective on why the LGBTQ+ community believes in Steven!

name: True Weird Stories from Video Game History
description:
Video games can get weird – not just the games themselves but the stories about them. In this late-night panel, four gaming historians will share their favorite strange, unbelievable tales from video game history, like a medical equipment game for the Game Boy Advance and a scandalous bug in an educational game.

Panelists:
Phil Salvador is a librarian, digital archivist, and video game historian who runs The Obscuritory, a blog about unusual and unknown old video games. He is a friend to all birds.

Kelsey Lewin creates mini-documentaries about odd and obscure topics from video game history on Youtube. She is also the co-owner of Seattle-based video game retailer Pink Gorilla Games, and is involved with various projects at the Video Game History Foundation.

Frank Cifaldi is the founder of The Video Game History Foundation, a non-profit dedicated to making sure the people of the future know everything they need to know about the games of today.

Rachel Simone Weil is an artist and video game historian whose work centers on preserving and reimagining femme aesthetics in 8- and 16-bit console gaming. She brings girly and glitchy visuals to obsolete hardware and game consoles, creating interactive electronic art that has been shown internationally in venues ranging from chipmusic festivals to fine art galleries. In 2012, Weil founded FEMICOM Museum, a physical and online collection of twentieth-century games and electronic toys for girls.

name: Dwelling of Duels
description:
Every month a fierce battle is conducted between musicians across the world. Dwelling of Duels pits them against each other to create the best covers and arrangements of video game songs possible, based off monthly themes. Every song has an instrument played live, whether it be guitar, keyboard or even trumpet. At the end of the month the entries are put online to be voted on by the community until a winner is selected.
"MAGFest Month" became a yearly tradition since 2006. The live listening party is being held at the festival for everybody to listen to the entries and hang out with the musicians who recorded them. Dancing may occur. Wandering cosplayers may drop in and run away in horror. The winning songs are determined by voting and the results are announced at the end of MAGFest.
This year's MAGFest Month is a battle of the ages: Pixels vs Polygons! Contestants pick their sides and cover pixelated or 3D games in the ultimate visual/auditory face-off!

name: DJ Battle feat. Bloodcode, Ralfington, Jadeabella, GRIMECRAFT, and James Landino
3D printable prop designing
description: Discussion on the basics of 3D printers, and designing props for 3D printers., as well as use of 3D print pens.

name: Late Night Madness with Wes Johnson
description: Wes Johnson brings the madness of Sheogorath, the ruthlessness of Lucien Lachance, the cleverness of Hermaeus Mora and the vocabulary of Fawkes to his own late night panel. New animation from Max Johnson will be shown! What happens in Wes' Late Night Panel STAYS in Wes' Late Night Panel.

name: Bowser: Behind the Koopa Curtain
description: Bowser may be known as the notorious King Koopa, but what you may not know is the captivating history and fashionable lifestyle of this notorious, fire-breathing celebrity. Maybe if we’re lucky we can even get him to open up about Bowsette... Join us as we take a look inside the luxurious, high-profile adventures of this famous antagonist and try not to walk away feeling too burnt out.

name: MSX Computers: The New Standard for Retro Sound
description: The MSX Standard is the future for true, authentic video game music from hardware!  Join Steve Lakawicz (chiptune's "ap0c" / co-host of Retro Game Audio) as he explains how to use MSX standard computers to play audio files from everything from Sega Master System to Sharp X-1 Turbo to PC-98 - all off authentic sound chips.  Learn how to buy/build/assemble your own compact home hardware listening station!

name: Full Motion Videoke!
description: Full-Motion Videoke is back at SuperMAG for the third time! You know about karaoke? Well, this is karaoke with video game cut scenes and game-based movie scenes. Join Fard Muhammad (from "Jesus Bro" and "Disco") as you select a scene, get on stage, and be awesome!

description: A showcase of memorable, forgotten, and just plain weird video game commercials to air in the US from the early 80s to the 2000s. You'll see a family forced into an F-1 race, mascot costumes running amok, and a company that does what their competitor don't.

name: The Return of Sonic Fights Robotnik Fanfic: Live!
description: Back in 1998 a legend was born. His real name has been lost to time, but those who remember still whisper one word...SonicFan. Join Dom, BigAdam, and the SAGE crew as they perform a live reading of the third installment of the story nobody asked to hear.

name: You Got Your Disney in my Final Fantasy! Kingdom Hearts for Beginners
description:
With Kingdom Hearts III coming out at the end of the month, the craze around this series is at an all-time high. But it's also a series known for being super confusing and dense. What's a newcomer to do?

Never fear, for we'll crack into this crazy mash-up and make it simple to fall in love with Sora, Donald, and Goofy. No prior knowledge of the series is required.

name: How Neopets Taught Me to Lie and Made Me a Furry : The Rise and Fall of Neopets
description: Neopets veterans invite you for a discussion on how the virtual pets website Neopets influenced 90s kids who grew up with it as a main source of fandom. We will give an overview of the timeline of the site, from its creation in 1999 to present day. We will explain how Neopets taught us how to navigate the internet, friendships, and creating content from risqué Neopets illustrations to custom html code. Other topics include cosplay, the Neopian economy, the decline of the website, how Neopets influence fan culture, the relation with LGBT+ topics, games on the website, handheld devices, consoles, and the trading card game.

name: Morning GSdOnuts: A Nerdy Networking Breakfast
description:
Come level up your networking stats and hopefully add some new names to your friend lists too! Networking in the gaming and music industries may sound intimidating, but it's really just a fancy word for making new friends that you want to work with on cool stuff, and there's no better place to make new friends than MAGFest! Attendees are encouraged to bring their best networking tips, stories, and business cards, because this is NOT a lecture. We'll be having a round table discussion on our various organizations, projects, how to effectively network and collaborate with individuals and groups, and more. Stop by, you never know who you might meet!

Suggested Attire: Gamer Casual

name: Conversion for Imersion
description: Don't just tell your friends about the awesome video game you just played, give them a genuine first hand experience. This panel will discuss many successful techniques as well as a few do's and don'ts for attempting to convert video games and and other media into an interactive role-play experience for your players. We'll be discussing the types of media including video games and movies that work best in these situations, the types of settings that work best, and how it can be shared with others, as well as citing some of the best experiences people have had with these types of games right here at MAGFest!

name: Mega Man X3: Zero Project

HCHecxz walks us through the fan mod of Mega Man X3 where you can play the entire game as Zero!

name: Archiverse - The Miiverse Archive Project: One Year Later
description:
In early 2018, Archiverse, Archive Teams Miiverse Archive Project, was launched. It was a huge hit, letting anyone, letting anyone log in and access over 17 terabytes of lost posts, screenshots, and drawings going from the very first posts published to the last one submitted.

In this talk, we'll give a brief history of Miiverse and Nintendo's decision to shut it down, how the archive was performed, the launch of Archiverse and all of the media attention it attracted, its aftereffects one year later, and where we go from here for online game preservation.

name: Killer Queen Field Game
description:
Killer Queen Field Game is the game that inspired the arcade classic and has the same three ways to win! Military, Economic, and Snail! Like its arcade heir, it's a team-based game akin to Capture the Flag. Be prepared for lots of running, strategizing, and swashbuckling!

The game will be played in best of 3 matches many times over the course of two hour session, so feel free to drop in at any point.

name: Open and Guided Jams
description:
Bring your instrument (or try our in-house gear), grab a microphone, and get ready to jam with our highly-talented staff and guests! Or just swing by and enjoy the live music! Not sure where to start, or want to brush up on your chops? We have workshops scheduled throughout the weekend for all skill levels.

Note: time ranges for Open and Guided Jams may vary slightly due to scheduled events in the Jam Clinic and Jam Shop.

~~~

The Jam Clinic is a musician-to-musician education venue at the Music and Gaming Festival (MAGFest), dedicated to co-mentoring participants on how to play and improvise within genres such as jazz fusion, funk, and rock, as well as popular video game music.

We strive to teach participants and empower them with the language of musical communication, while embracing a leadership-centered, technology-powered, challenging, and fun atmosphere for our visitors.

name: Open Jam
description: Jamspace Open Jam: Apple Butter (not rly jam, I know, but it's better, so w/e)

name: Morning Free Form Larps
description:
FreeForm Larps: Friday 10am-2pm Saturday 10am-2pm 
 Damocles Thread Development presents a selection FreeForm Larps. Free Form gaming is a very different experience for people who have never tried it before. The games will push people to become emotionally attached to their characters and deal with situations realistically. Come by and try something new with our FreeForm Larps. The selection available will vary each morning but may include.

Wight Wedding: A freeform LARP about a wedding like any other -- except half the guests are dead, and some have unfinished business. This is a comedy game with some horror and tragedy elements. 
Recipe: Competitive Cooking Show!: A freeform LARP about your favorite Food Network reality shows, where you are a judge or a competitor trying to impress! Can you make a delicious dish with just truffles, truffle oil, and truffle salt? As this is an improv game, no actual food will be provided, but the fun will be in abundance!

Sins of the Father: A multigenerational hell. The Barbatos family has a deep dark secret, and it's not the embezzling, the murders, the incest, or the rampant narcissism. Each generation, the cousins gather to decide which of them will sell their soul for the good of the family. It isn’t just figurative language about the evils of money perverting the souls of those who do what it takes to make it. No, the Barbatos family is in bed with the Devil in the most literal of ways.  

The Porch: It’s the last day of summer before you head off to your freshman year of college, or the military, or just back to your shitty job at the gas station. You’re hanging out with all your small-town high school friends. Each one of you has a burning question you can’t ask
Shattered Hero: The greatest hero of the world has fallen, and now all that’s left are her friends to try and pick up the pieces. Play as the companions as they enter the mind of their fallen comrade and rebuild her mind, but are they rebuilding her, or who they thought she was?

name: What’s the Toy Story?  A brief history of toys and what game designers can learn from them.
description: This talk will take participants through the history of how some of the most iconic toys of our times came to be, look at the intersection of toys and video games and discuss why toys are one of the BEST design tools for making your own games.

name: Inclusivity in Gaming: ASD at Your FLGS
description: This short presentation is designed for proprietors and patrons of Friendly Local Game Stores.  The training explains Autism Spectrum Disorders and gives some helpful insight into how people with this diagnosis experience Autism and how we can be more understanding and inclusive in the gaming environment.  Understanding how to set boundaries and be inclusive helps make sure that Everybody Plays!

name: Introduction to Kids Game Design with PBS KIDS
description: Meet the PBS KIDS team and learn how they make game for kids. A panel of members from different areas of the process will walk through how they help create games

name: Artist's Meetup & Swap
description: Come meet other artists and swap your SFW art prints or extras of your favorite artist supplies. Traditional and digital artists of all skill levels are welcome to join. No money exchanged, just swaps and appreciation of everyone's unique art style. Since this is open to all skill levels, please be kind and encouraging towards budding artistic talent.

name: The Deadliest SOB in Space: Realities of Space Combat
description: Back for its second year! Do you think you were born in the wrong century? Were you meant to be a space warrior? Then turn off that space sim, put away those paperbacks and get yourself over to this panel, recruit! Consider this your first training session in orbital combat – but not the kind you’ve seen on TV. We're talking real physics, engineering, and tactics. It might not always be as glamorous as sci-fi, but sometimes truth has a way of being more interesting than fiction. This year is all about space weapons, and you might be surprised at how some of the latest research is making even recent media look a bit dated…

name: SUPER Double NintenDare!
description: On your mark… get set… GO! Double NintenDare is a Nintendo-themed throwback to the classic kids’ gameshow of a similar name. Put your knowledge and skill of classic and current Nintendo games to the test by answering tricky trivia questions or taking on our special "Digital Challenges" and finishing the dreaded Mario Maker Obstacle Course! Each player will receive fabulous prizes whether you win or lose, and we’ll take you back in time with classic 90s commercials in between rounds.

name: Marvel Now:  Highlights!
description: Looking to read some recent Marvel comics?  Join us, as we dive into our long boxes and pick some of the best runs and events of the last 5 years of Marvel Comics.

name: The History of Video Game Music
description: Join the Super Marcato Bros. as they take an in-depth, chronological journey exploring video game music through the years. They start from the earliest days on consoles such as the Atari 2600, and move all the way up to the modern day. This is a unique and extensive look at how video game music has evolved over the years, what has changed and what hasn't.

name: Cooperation: We're in Games Together
description: This panel is about cooperation in games. How it exists, and how we can better design for it to encourage prosocial out comes in players. Cooperation can mean local co-op, internet based play, or even partnering with NPCs. At the crux of the play style its about how we work and achieve together. We will be discussing games that have done it right (and wrong) as well as how iThrive Games has been working to make this a more intentional design aspect.

name: RPG Design Series: Advanced RPG Design
description:
This panel will go into advanced topics in RPG design such as combat mechanics, skill/class balance, and enemy design.
This panel will consist of a presentation and a group discussion, followed by answering questions from the audience.

description:
Plan the Heist of the Century!

Amid violence in the streets of Waterdeep, six unlikely criminals plan the heist of the century, hoping to grab the key to a fortune in gold coins.  This 8-hour event uses pregenerated characters.  Compete for prizes, fun, and the ultimate in roleplaying glory: winner of the D&D Open!  Players also earn rewards applicable toward their D&D Adventurers League characters.  No experience needed, all materials provided.

Preregister for this event here: https://reggie.magfest.org/attractions/

name: Overwatch Tournament Casting
description: Come watch the finale of the Overwatch tournament in the LAN Theatre!

name: Building your first VR game for Oculus Go
description: John will walk you step by step through the design, build and deployment process for creating a Virtual Reality game for Oculus Go headset in Unity 3D.

name: Accessibility in Games: Better Games for Everyone
description: When developers make games with people with disabilities in mind, they make better games for everyone. For example, including captions on cutscenes not only helps people with hearing loss, but it helps the person with broken headphones or the gamer who's trying to play in class (not that we recommend that). We'll go over best practices and design tips for creating game components like HUDs, controls, mechanics, and audio/visuals that are disability-friendly and a better experience for all players.

name: Roleplaying Games and Romantic Relationships
description: This panel explores the role of romantic relationships and how they can impact  roleplaying games. Not to be confused with romantic roleplay, that's a private affair. Rather, this panel will look at how real-life relationships can enhance or hinder group roleplaying games. While it's not uncommon to find couples who enjoy roleplaying games, how can they play together and with others in a meaningful way without physical, social, or mental harm. We will discuss practical advice for couples who want to play together and for others who may have to deal with obnoxious lovebirds or toxic train-wrecks.

name: Chainmail D20 Cage Workshop
description: In this "make and take" workshop we will create a caged D20 that you can use as a keychain or pendant to take die on the go. Class kits including chainmail supplies and a D20 will be available for $10 (limited to 15 kits) or you may bring your own supplies. Loaner tools will also be available to use during the workshop.

name: Game Music Guest Composers Q&A
description:
Come and ask your friendly Game Composers anything you'd like. Featuring composers from 
Celeste, Deus Ex, Unreal Tournament, Cuphead, Command & Conquer and more!

name: Simulating Game Mechanics In Literature
description: Gameplay is as vital to a good video game as the narrative, so how do aspiring writers incorporate the gameplay elements into other media?  Join this discussion of how video game mechanics can be turned into narrative elements for literature, film, and comics.  Platformers, FPS, RPGs, and RTS games will all be discussed.

name: Starfox: Armada or How I Single Handedly Saved the Franchise.
description: Remember those halcyon days of SNES and N64-era Starfox? Whatever happened to those days? How can we get that feeling back again? In this panel, I discuss a foolproof plan to create a game for the Starfox series that would pull it out of its funk FOREVER.

ProtomagicalGirl speeds through Mega Man 6!

name: Arranging Video Game Music: Concepts and Tools
description: Have you ever heard an amazingly-creative cover of your favorite classic VGM theme and thought, "How did they come up with that?" In this combination workshop-performance event, members of contemporary Jazz/Pop/Rock/Fusion orchestra "The 8-Bit Big Band" will touch on instrument arranging and orchestrating techniques for video game music of all ensemble sizes! We will discuss and demonstrate the various components of an arrangement, and present examples of how to utilize them in order to add color, contour, and excitement. Example topics covered include: genre, song form, re-harmonization, instrumentation, and orchestration techniques.

name: Heroes of the Storm 5v5 Tournament
description: Keeping a stable presence this year, this Blizzard mash-up MOBA brings the map-based objective action to Magfest.

name: Bland Games: Defining Mediocrity and the Middlebrow
description: This panel will carve out a critical and aesthetic space for "bland games," a nebulous moniker that isn't an embrace of paragaming (deliberately praising the bad), nor a celebration of excellence (the canon). By looking at examples from throughout the history of videogames, the talk and discussion will generate strategies for defining and talking about the bland and unremarkable games that encompass so much of the history of the medium.

name: PBS KIDS mini Juice Box Jam!
description: Join the PBS KIDS Team in learning and trying your hand at designing games for kids!

name: Band Merch sales
description: Hours of Operations

name: Wargaming: Gaming for National Security
description: Wargaming is more than a hobby. Gaming provides a powerful tool for education, training and analysis and is used every day across the Department of Defense and broader national security community. Wargaming can range from virtual environments such as Virtual Battlespace 3, to complex algorithmic models, to physical sand table combat with miniatures, to roleplay based crisis decision-making exercises. These should all sound familiar as they share a heritage and techniques with the games many people outside of the national security community play. Join us to learn more about the world of professional wargaming and how it relates to your games.

name: Yoga For Gamers
description: Reflect, restore, and reboot your personal "system"-- your body-mind-breath complex. Join me in an all-welcome, all-levels meditation and movement practice, accompanied by gaming themes and music for inspiration. This isn't about "exercising"; it's about connecting the circuits within yourself, and observing the nature of the mind as it renders your personal gameworld. Self-awareness = Choice. Choose your adventure.

name: Man At Arms: An Inside Look
description: Man At Arms - The cast of your favorite youtube & TV show give you “An Inside Look” into the show. This is your chance to get a behind the scenes look, meet the cast and learn how weapons are chosen. Plus, find out how it all comes together. There will be a Q&A at the end of the panel, so have your questions forged and ready to go. If your lucky, they might even show you some exclusive footage!

name: Star Fox - Race
description: To start off the MAGfast block, we've got Nate Horsefall and Steve of Super Guitar Bros. racing to see who's the fastest at the original Star Fox on SNES.

name: Super Mario Strikers (GC)
description:
Consoles Tournament 

Please arrive at Consoles Op 15 minutes before start of tournament.

name: Rainbow 6: Siege 5v5 Tournament
description: Come coordinate with your squad to gain tactical supremacy in this objective-based FPS.

name: Stairway to Rhythm Heaven
description:
Retronauts regulars Jeremy Parish, Bob Mackey, and Chris Sims explore the sonic legacy of Nintendo's most inventively musical team, the R&D1 division. For 20 years, the R&D1 team pushed the boundaries of sound design in games in fascinating ways, culminating in the inventively nutty Rhythm Heaven series. We look back at two decades of audible genius, from Gyromite to Wario and beyond.

Panelists:
The Retronauts podcast, cohosted by Jeremy Parish and Bob Mackey, has been running in various incarnations since 2006 and focuses on classic video games and related media. You can find it at retronauts.com.

name: We Built a Better World:  How Setting Affects Narrative Play
description: Have you ever played a game and just been unable to get into it?  Did the game world seem too small, or too bland, or just too fake?  Conversely, have you ever been so enmeshed in the environment that you wound up neglecting (or ignoring!) the primary objectives? Players always notice the differences between a neglected world and a compelling one, but what is it that makes a game world seem full and robust?  What do we look for in a setting that invites us to explore, and to seek out the fullest depths of what the game has to offer?

name: Learn Famitracker in an hour
description: Learn a thing or two about creating a chiptune in this special workshop at Magfest!

name: Let's Play: Super Art Fight's CUTE ANIMALS ON FIRE
description: Last year, MAGFest favorites Super Art Fight kickstarted a card game. Now, it's a REAL game, and they want to play it with YOU! Join the SAF Roster in a laugh-filled mile-a-minute game of CUTE ANIMALS ON FIRE!

name: X-strike Studios Returns
description: X-strike Studios is back! Well, we're getting there at least. Come find out what your favorite recently-resurrected video game parody company is plotting for the future.

name: Creating Compelling AR Experiences With ARKit
description: Hear from longtime Apple Developer John Nelson as he breaks down the features of Apple’s ARKit API and Apple’s SwiftShot AR demo game presented at 2018's World Wide Developer Conference

name: Drive robots, Make/shoot pneumatic rockets, 3D Printing demonstrations
description: Come see and try out various types of robots from Lego, VEX and FIRST.  Make paper rockets and shoot them with our air powered launcher.  We’ll also be doing some 3D printing and showing attendees how we scan and use CAD to create original designs.

name: MITS Showcases 3
description:
Come to see the following teams as they showcase their games:

AX!OM - Pummel your enemies with aliens in this unique battle-card brawler!

Off the Shelf Games
Mech Deck - Mech build and battle game

One Method Monkey LLC
Hero's Crossing - Be the mayor of a town in an RPG, managing the shops and smithies to outfit heroes in a strategy board game realized with beautiful pixel art!

Pie for Breakfast Studios
La Mancha - Create your own legend with La Mancha, the award-winning storytelling game based on the classic novel, Don Quixote!

Rock Manor Games
Set a Watch - Set a Watch is a 60 minute, cooperative adventure puzzle game for 1-4 players.
The Few and Cursed - The Few and Cursed is a deckbuilding adventure game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic earth where most of the water on the planet has been gone for seventy years.

name: Foiled Tournament
description: Win MAGBucks playing on the Foiled arcade machine!

name: So You Wanna Study Games? From Joysticks to Journal Articles
description: If you're thinking about studying games academically and not just playing them, this panel's for you! Games academics share their advice on how to pursue the academic study of games, from undergrad to advanced degrees!

name: You Got Thundercats in my D&D: Introducing Pop Culture Characters to Tabletop RPG's
description:
Snake Plissken, Rose Quartz, Mister Freeze, and three Power Rangers walk into a tavern....

Sounds like the start of a bad joke, right? But considering that pop culture characters give us a wealth of inspiration and great jumping-off points for our RPG adventures, it can be fun to have a Bounty Hunter themed campaign. We'll discuss how starting with such an established template can help players of all experience levels get into character, and how these characters can flex your creative muscles in new ways. This will be a guided conversation with some exercises, and participation is encouraged. No experience is required.

name: Catan (Board Game)
description:
Half Empty E-Tank and friends play a nice friendly game of Settlers of Catan. Nothing would ever come up that could end friendships. Ever. 

1:50 - 3:50 PM

name: Killer Queen (Bring Your Own Team)
description:

name: From Alphie to Zelda: Preserving the History of Video Games at The Strong
description:
Staff from The Strong in Rochester, NY - home to the International Center for the History of Electronic Games and the Brian Sutton-Smith Library & Archives of Play - discuss the unique collections, preservation projects, and other initiatives that comprise the museum's efforts to preserve the history of video games.

Panelists:
As the Director of Libraries at The Strong, Beth Lathrop oversees the Brian Sutton-Smith Library and Archives of Play and the Grada Hopeman Gelser Library. The Brian Sutton-Smith Library and Archives of Play is a multidisciplinary research repository devoted to the intellectual, social, and cultural history of play, which holds scholarly works, professional journals, trade catalogs, press kits, children’s books, comic books, manuscripts, personal papers, business records, design documents, schematics, source code, and more. Beth is a graduate of James Madison University and holds a Master’s of Library Science degree from the University at Buffalo. She also holds a certificate in non-profit management from St. John Fisher College.

As digital games curator at The Strong, Andrew coordinates the museum’s efforts related to digital preservation of electronic games. He holds both an undergraduate and master's degree in Information Science, with a concentration in school media, and he has taught library classes for students in Kindergarten through 12th grade. He has long taken an active role in game preservation, focusing on the preservation of unreleased game prototypes and development material.

name: Culture in Occupation: The Evolution of Japanese Game and Film Composition after World War II
description: Japanese music is known for its distinctive tunes, harmonic language, and incredible sense of space. However, few people have really taken the time to do a proper historical deep-dive on why the music in games and anime have turned out the way they have. Well... We did!

name: Beginner’s Guide to Cosplay Makeup
description: A step by step guide to basic makeup techniques for all! Such as eye liner, eye shadows, mascara, contouring, highlights, and gender defying goals. Come and ask experienced makeup artists and cosplayers. Learn helpful hints and tricks for the aesthetic of your dreams.

description: Do you have an awesome costume? Come up on stage and show us your moves! All ages and skill levels are welcome! All entries will get a chance to be in character and tell the audience about their costume. Our judges will select 16 entries to move forward in the competition, and then its all up to the audience who wins!  Prizes for everyone who competes! Awards will be given for both on stage presentation and craftsmanship. Lineup starts at 1:30!

name: Lo-Fi and Cover Music; Why it's good & why everyone loves it
description: a discussion on the emerging popularity of Lo-Fi music as well as the notoriety singers and songwriters making cover songs of video game music, as well as some professional tips on how to write/improve Lo-Fi tracks and how to get started as a Cover artist.

name: VR/AR for Museums
description: Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality have the ability to enhance education for visitors to museums.  Learn key concepts on museum exhibit design, logistics of VR technology within exhibit space, and how to design VR/AR experiences that are intuitive for visitors who have never tried the technology before.  We will cover several issues of incorporating both AR and VR in large public venues and how they may incorporated into exhibit space.

name: Curious Quail
description: Started as an ill-advised solo project mashing fuzzy guitar rock, orchestral instrumentation and the sounds of 80’s and 90’s video game hardware, Curious Quail has evolved into more of a musician collective than a band proper with contributing members spanning the west coast of the United States from the deserts of the Coachella Valley to the Bay Area and the Pacific Northwest. Their mission has remained one of writing music that showcases an ongoing storyline told through lyrics and musical motifs while over engineering every technical decision from “how can we add more violin” to “yes the Gameboy needs an overdrive pedal”. They’re releasing two records this year; Empty Victories, and a nontraditional monthly writing exercise called Twelve Months, which is partially available on YouTube as you read this.

name: The Sims, its History, and its Communities
description:
Described by its creator as more a toy than a game, The Sims's open-ended gameplay and moddability changed the way that a lot of us thought about video games and the kinds of people who play them. Nearly nineteen years later, we look back on the PC gaming juggernaut, its history, and the kinds of online communities it created. From modders to builders to storytellers, come take a look at the diverse ways that players interact with both their games and their fellows.

Panelist:
Campbell Parker (StrangetownFunk) is a dev and blogger from the DC area. She has been participating in the Sims's online communities for over a decade and thinks of the series as an important part of video game history.

name: Hustle and Flow: Real talk on Making it
description: It’s easy to see people where you want to be, but we don’t talk about how they had to hustle, grind and work to get “there”. Let’s have some real talk on what you don’t see beyond the name and fame; especially about what some people think success looks like versus what it is

name: Indie Game Real Talk 3: Quit Your Day Job Edition
description: Join Sheena Perez and Travis Rupp-Greene of Albino Moose Games (known for their work on Spooky's Jump Scare Mansion), the Video Game Attorney Ryan Morrison and 3D artist Phillip Fortunat as they talk about all things game industry. Learn about the legal side, the art side and the developer side of video games and the honest truth behind it all. Like it or not.

name: Everyone can game: Accessible gaming for individuals with disabilities.
description: Independence is a right, not a privilege. With gaming being better than ever some gamers feel left out due to a lack of perceived accessibility options. This panel talks about new and old adaptations, accommodations, and accessibility options for those with a range of challenges. Everyone is welcome, everyone can game.

Following on from the Wargaming: Gaming for National Security, this panel will examine a series of U.S. and international wargames to explore wargaming techniques and applications. The panel will be draw on public historical and contemporary wargames that examine different uses of wargaming. Audience members will be able to use the Q&A steer the discussion and dive deeper into specific elements of wargaming.

name: The Strange Death of the Nintendo Entertainment System
description:
Nintendo's NES console quietly died in 1995 after its last official games came out in Europe...or so the story usually goes. But a combination of third-world manufacturing, patent expirations, and the birth of emulators means that not a year has gone by without brand new NES games being made, usually in places you wouldn't think to look. Join Video Game History Foundation director Frank Cifaldi as we look at the weird, wild, unexplored world of the NES' post-mortem years.

Panelist:
Frank Cifaldi is the founder of The Video Game History Foundation, a non-profit dedicated to making sure the people of the future know everything they need to know about the games of today.

name: Songs of Time: Exploring the Man Behind the Music of The Legend of Zelda
description: Koji Kondo’s music is that of great efficiency and precision. In under 2 seconds, he can uncover a secret passageway and all the mystery beyond it. And with only 4 notes, he can create 18 distinct themes with entirely different moods. Through an analysis of ocarina themes, musical cues, and background music, this lecture will examine how Koji Kondo pulls the absolute most out of his briefest melodies in The Legend of Zelda series.

name: Discovering Z-Brush

name: Retro Game Collecting:  Do's Don'ts, and Things To Consider
description: As someone who has collected retro video games "before it was cool", Ben has amassed a collection of thousands of games, from the common and cheap, to the rare, obscure, and expensive.  During this panel, Ben will discuss things to think about if you are getting into game collecting, or are looking to improve your game collecting strategy.  We will talk about things like proper protection and cleaning, finding items at a good price, how to determine what kinds of items you collect and motivations for collecting.  There will also be a Q&A where Ben will answer questions.  This panel is about what the audience wants to learn, so an active audience is appreciated!

name: SiIvaGunner Presents: High Quality Ripping
description: SiIvaGunner is a YouTube channel that uploads unedited video game music. Now, three years after the channel's inception, some of the SiIvaGunner manager staff will be discussing high quality video game music, the intricacies of ripping it and many more interesting factoids about the work that goes into the channel. description: Panelists will discuss 10 proposed different constitutional amendments. The amendments have been submitted by game designers across the country (and a few from the panelists themselves). Hear them talk about what part of the system they are trying to patch, then politely raise your hand so you can scream at them at tell them why they are crazy and should be going back to designing games and leave politics to the Russians. Note: This is NOT a panel about policy, it’s about structure.

name: Careers Paths in Audio
description: This panel is a discussion of the different possible career paths in the audio industry. Hosted by Audio Designers Isabella Ness and Josie Brechner, Audio Director Marc Straight, and DJ Novil Fullen we will discuss our introductions and experiences within games, film, and live performances. Afterwards, we will go further into detail on other, roads less traveled along with an open Q&A.

name: Recording Better Voiceovers: The Tools and Techniques to Achieve a Professional Sound.
description: The tools to make professional sounding voiceovers and podcasts have never been more accessible.  In this lecture we will discuss microphone choice, isolation, plugins, and simple techniques that can take your sound to the next level.  Volunteers are welcome.

name: Midnight Snacks
description:
7:00-7:30 pm- skybox b2b GWIZ
7:30-8:00 pm- DJ HYPE☆GIRL b2b Hiero

name: Working Both Sides: VGM Composers and their anime work
description: Did you know the composers behind NieR wrote over 30 pop songs for anime? Or Yoko Kanno of Cowboy Bebop fame was first famous for her work on Tecmo Koei's Romance of the Three Kingdoms series? VGM and anime music are intrinsically intertwined, but the giants of VGM's work on anime is often criminally overlooked. In this panel, we'll examine the anime works of some of your favorite VGM composers and how their styles can drastically change (or not) when working on both mediums.

name: Folklore in Video Games
description: Back before the widespread nature of the internet, where any walkthrough of a game can be found within minutes, video games developed a sort of “folklore” culture. Fans would theorize and spread through word of mouth the existence of Missingo or how they beat Sub-Zero in Mortal Kombat. Nowadays, rumors of how to do something in a video game are uncommon due to data mining and internet sleuths. But can games still cultivate a folklore, despite this internet age? Come see us break down the history of folklore surrounding video games, and discuss the possible modern-day incarnations of playground rumors.

name: How to create audio for your game without a budget
description: Do you have a game or maybe a movie? Now you need sound and you have no money. This panel endeavors to show you how to create original immersive sound without a budget. What to expect? A short lecture, some video examples, and hands-on participation with the tools of my daily trade. Followed by a Q&A session

name: Super Art Fight
description: The Greatest Live Art Competition in the Known Universe returns to MAGFest! Two (or more!) artists collide on a giant wall of canvas as you cheer your favorites on to victory! But watch out for the ever unpredictable WHEEL OF DEATH, filled with drawing topics submitted online! To submit topics or check out the show card, head to SuperArtFight.com!

name: Materia Collective, the VGM Scene, and You
description:
Since it's 2015 debut album, Materia Collective has been releasing albums that bring musicians from all over the world together to celebrate their favorite game soundtracks. Materia Collective has grown since then to include original soundtracks, solo cover albums, and even sheet music in its repertoire, alongside its sprawling community cover albums. 

So - how can you get involved? The answer to that question depends! Do you want to join a community of game music-minded friends? Do you want musicians to collaborate and jam with? Do you want to see your original soundtracks published, or perform for other composers? There are so many possible directions for getting involved in video game music, and Materia Collective has a hand in most of them, giving the organization a unique perspective on the opportunities you have available. 

A panel of members from the Materia Collective community will talk about what, exactly, Materia Collective is, the different projects Materia Collective is involved with, and how artists can join in on the action.

name: Esports 101: Managing a Team
description: Are you a gamer who is interested in entering the world of Esports and tournaments, either as a player or management worker? Here is where Mikomi will talk about how she formed a team out of her friends and built them into a sponsored team that competes on the international level.

name: Super Soul Bros
description:
The Super Soul Bros. are what would happen if you jammed

a 70’s Herbie Hancock record into a Super Nintendo. 

ABOUT THE BAND
BIOS

CHRISTIAN MANZANA
Trombone
Christian has been playing professionally for eight years, and is proficient in many styles of music, playing with groups that range from classical, salsa, jazz, hip-hop, R&B, and funk. He has played with R&B/soul legend Aretha Franklin, toured Europe with The Stanford Jazz Orchestra featuring trumpeter Jon Faddis, and has played in European jazz festivals such as the Jazz À Vienne and the Montreaux Jazz Festival. He’s currently finishing a Master’s Degree in Jazz Studies at San Jose State University. 


CHRIS HAMAN
Drums
Chris Haman is a drummer and percussionist who specializes in rock, jazz, latin, metal, hip hop, and more. With a strong interest in many genres of music, Haman tends to meld a variety of styles into his own playing. Growing up, he was constantly forming bands with friends, schoolmates, and anyone who matched his passion for music. Haman earned his music degree at San Jose State University with an emphasis in jazz. He teaches drum lessons and plays professionally throughout the Bay Area.


BRIAN SHEU
Guitar / Co-Leader
Brian Sheu is a funk/jazz/fusion guitar player. Brian plays with a unique approach that incorporates a multitude of styles like rock, metal, classical, hip hop, and R&B.  He attended the Musician’s Institute in LA from 2009-2011, and attained the school’s highest honor, being named the “Most Outstanding Guitar Player” of the graduating group.  Brian has studied under many of the masters, including Paul Gilbert (Mr. Big), Scott Henderson (Tribal Tech), Charles Altura (Chick Corea), Doug Rappaport (Edgar Winter),  Allen Hinds, and many more.


ROBBIE BENSON
Keyboards / Bandleader
Starting at the age of 2, Robbie’s piano playing was guided by his father Eric Benson—a Hammond B3 organ player. Robbie has since had the pleasure of performing as a sideman for Ron E. Beck (Tower of Power), Tony Lindsay (Santana), Napoleon Murphy Brock (Frank Zappa), and Danny Hull (Doobie Brothers), as well as studying with the likes of Russell Ferrante (Yellowjackets). Now taking the role of frontman and bandleader, Robbie has focused on his latest project, Super Soul Bros.

Based in San Jose, CA, the Super Soul Bros (not “Brothers”) combine explosive funk-fusion and jazz with familiar melodies from classic video game, anime, TV and movie soundtracks. Since their formation in 2012 by keyboardist Robbie Benson, they’ve become renowned for their dynamic musicianship, improvisation, and high energy shows.

name: Psychological Tricks of the Dungeon Master
description: Many years ago I did a study about how Dungeon Masters in Dungeons & Dragons and other Tabletop Roleplaying Games use psychological tricks to to keep players engaged, keep them on the path of their adventure, and keep them motivated to come back for more. With tabletop gaming experiencing a resurgence, people are always looking for DMing advice and ways to make their table better. Let's talk about how to be a better tabletop DM... with science!

name: Read the Rules!
description: Videogames enforce their own rules (usually). In tabletop however, the players themselves must do this. The only guide they have: the rulebook(s). Do you read the rules? Did anyone? How do so many people (as evidenced by the BoardGameGeek forums and Reddit threads) get things so horribly, horribly wrong? From Euros to RPGs, our panel of experts (plus those GeekNights guys) will consider how, why, and where the rules are misinterpreted, ignored, broken, or lost.

name: MAGFest Musicians' Roundtable and Feedback Session: A Future for the Jam Clinic
description:
For many, the Jam Clinic (and Jam Shop) is a place dedicated to bringing attendees together for a weekend full of amazing jam sessions, educational workshops for all skill levels, and plenty of unexpected musical surprises. But what is the long-term outlook in the face of an ever-changing, diversifying, and growing MAGFest? What are we currently doing to reach out to others beyond this organization?

Kevin Lin, the founder and department head of the Jam Clinic, along with his staff members, invite you to join us for a moderated roundtable discussion on the future of this venue, and how we can continue serving and adapting to the video game production, music composition/arrangement, and STEAM education community. This is not only an open feedback session, but also a brainstorming and networking event for sharing ideas and catalyzing action to help us grow for years to come.

name: Post Production Workflows and Technology in Online Video Environments

name: The Path of Falcom: Adventures of Ys and Trails
description:
Join seasoned members of the Nihon Falcom fandom to appreciate two great game franchises: the action-heavy Ys series and the sprawling Trails saga of JRPGs. Despite being one of the most talented and historic game developers around, Falcom struggles to get Ys and Trails localized outside Japan. We're here to discuss these games, the community around them, and what's next for Falcom!

We've prepared an hour of goodness: game showcases, fan creations, rich Q&A, and audio-visual delight. Whether you're already a fan or new to Falcom and these series, there's something for everyone. Expect fan translation news, superlative soundtracks, and audience games! Other topics include how to pronounce "Ys", what the Trails even are, and why that suspicious cat mascot appears in every game.

Finally, we might have a limited-exclusive surprise just for MAGFest! Be sure to stop by and stick around if you're keen on enjoying an underrated world of games, stories, and tunes.

name: Phantasy Star II: A 30 Year Retrospective

Join us as we look at this gem and discuss what makes it so great 30 years later.

name: Pinball's Controversial Past and (Hopefully) Awesome Future
description: Pinball's past is fraught with controversy, starting with citywide bans in the 1930's and '40's (to the point where the mayor of New York smashed them in the street with a sledgehammer), to its re-legalization decades later, to its supremacy in the '80's and '90's, to how it almost disappeared from the face of the earth at the end of the millennium.  The most interesting time in the history of pinball might actually be right now--the game is more popular than it's been in a quarter century.  This panel will examine the rocky road pinball has traveled and the unlikely reasons that, in an era when everyone carries unlimited video games on a glass rectangle in their pocket, a 250-pound behemoth of plywood, plastic, and steel is somehow growing in popularity.

name: Proton Torpedo: The Quest to Bring Every Steam Game to Linux
description:
As of 2018, Steam for Linux now has over 3000 games to choose from that were built as native programs, and the list grows every day. Linux gaming has a bright future, but the past continues to cast a very dark shadow over all of the work that brought us here. There are thousands of games available only for Windows that have long since been abandoned by developers, but not by players, putting Linux in a very uncomfortable position. Valve, CodeWeavers, and a handful of others are now working on Proton, a runtime specifically designed for Steam that sets out to bring the entire Steam catalog to Linux. Publicly branded as “Steam Play”, Proton allows Windows games to be downloaded to a Linux PC, installed in an isolated sandbox, and executed seamlessly as if it was a native application. This panel will discuss what Proton is, how it works, how developers can get involved, and most importantly, how customers can get involved as well. Ethan “flibitijibibo” Lee, developer of FNA, FAudio, and now bits and pieces of Proton, has over 50 Linux (native!) games of experience, including FEZ, Bastion, Owlboy, Rogue Legacy, TowerFall, Dust: An Elysian Tail, and many more!

This panel is independently run by Ethan and is not sponsored/endorsed by Valve or CodeWeavers
